texts.shortText:
Large gull with white head, neck, trailing edge of wing and underside; back and upper surface of wings black; outer primary feathers with white spots. Bill bright yellow with distinctive red spot on the underside. Eye dark brown with orange ring. Legs and feet dark yellow or dull green to grey. Juveniles mottled brown with dark bill.

There are five recognized subspecies in different parts of the range, the South Africa subspecies is named L. d. vetula and recognized by its slightly smaller, shorter bill and darker eyes.
Total length 49-65 cm, wingspan 128-142 cm mass 1000 g, sexes alike.

Global: Widespread across Southern Hemisphere with different sub-species in southern Africa; subantarctic islands in the Indian Ocean; Madagascar; the Antarctic; and in South America, Australia and New Zealand.

Local/Regional: Found along coast across whole region.

Predominantly coastal species, seldom found far inland or far out to sea. Common resident found in diverse marine, estuarine and coastal land habitats. Roosts at night in communal sites mostly on islands or coastal buildings, dispersing to feeding areas in the morning. Breeds on offshore islands and on coastal cliffs.

Generalist forager and scavenger feeding on a wide range of natural prey, as well as on scraps from fishing boats, on rubbish dumps, etc. Also take scraps from feeding seals at sea; scavenges for dead animals cast ashore after storms; puddles for invertebrates on beaches; drops large mussels or turban shells on rocks to crack their shells, etc. In terrestrial sites takes insects, berries, frogs, snakes and carrion. May also predate eggs and chicks of other seabirds, or rob them of food.

Monogamous and thought to retain same mate for successive years. Nest a shallow depression on the ground on islands or cliffs; lined with grass, twigs, shells, kelp and other debris. Usually lays 2-4 eggs that are off-white to blue-green, mottled with blotches or spots of black or brown. Incubation period 26-27 days; fledge after 46-73 days. Both parents brood and feed young.
Unmistakable and the only large gull in the region.

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 350).

Hockey, PAR, Dean, WRJ & Ryan, PG (2005). Robertâ€™s Birds of Southern Africa (7th edition). The Trustees of the John Voelckler Book Fund, Cape Town. (p. 439).
